description: File-based routing for Go. Fast to write. Faster to run. Build APIs and full-stack apps with conventions that feel natural.
rules: Always use file-based routing under the app/ directory
Route handlers must be named after HTTP methods (Get, Post, Put, Delete, etc.)
Use nexo.Context for handling requests and responses
Middleware must use factory pattern: func Middleware() nexo.MiddlewareFunc
Proxy functions must return *nexo.ProxyResult
Page templates must use templ syntax with the Page() component (with or without parameters)
Dynamic route directories use underscore prefix: _id for dynamic, __slug for catch-all, ___slug for optional catch-all
Route groups use _group_name prefix (e.g., _group_admin) and don't affect the URL
Page() parameter names should match directory names without the underscore prefix (e.g., _slug directory -> Page(slug string))
The underscore convention ensures all directories are valid Go package names without symlinks
If Page() parameters don't match URL parameters, a warning is shown but the page still renders
Layout templates must accept children... parameter
Use nexo generate commands for scaffolding new routes, middleware, pages, and proxies
Always run golangci-lint before committing to avoid CI failures
For deferred operations, use: defer func() { _ = file.Close() }()
Use c.JSON(status, data) for JSON responses
Use c.Bind(&struct) to parse JSON request bodies
Use c.Param(name) for URL parameters from _param directories
Use c.Query(name) for query string parameters
App-level request logger is enabled by default and captures ALL requests including proxy actions
Use app.SetLogger(nexo.RequestLoggerConfig{...}) to customize logging
Use NEXO_LOG_LEVEL environment variable to control log level (debug, info, warn, error)
In production (GO_ENV=production), log level defaults to warn; in dev mode, defaults to debug
Use HTMX attributes (hx-get, hx-post, hx-target, hx-swap) for interactive UI without JavaScript
Check c.IsHTMX() to detect HTMX requests and return partial HTML instead of full pages
Tailwind CSS v4 is built-in via standalone binary - no Node.js required
Run 'nexo tailwind build' for production CSS, 'nexo tailwind watch' for development
Place Tailwind source in styles/input.css, output goes to static/css/output.css
Use c.FormValue(name) to get form values from HTMX or traditional form submissions
For authentication, store user info in context with c.Set() and retrieve with c.Get()
Use nexo.BadRequest(), nexo.NotFound(), nexo.Unauthorized() for semantic error responses
Static files are served from static/ directory at /static path by default
Configure static file serving in nexo.yaml with static_dir and static_path options
Reference docs/api/middleware.mdx for built-in middleware configuration options
Reference docs/api/errors.mdx for error handling patterns and HTTPError struct
Reference docs/api/app.mdx for App struct methods and server lifecycle
Reference docs/api/proxy.mdx for ProxyResult actions (Continue, Redirect, Rewrite, ResponseJSON)
Use app.ServeOpenAPI() to enable automatic OpenAPI 3.1 specification generation
OpenAPI spec is served at /openapi.json, Swagger UI at /docs by default
Run 'nexo openapi generate' to create openapi.json file
Add comments above handler functions for automatic API documentation
Comments are extracted for OpenAPI: first line = summary, rest = description
Tags are automatically derived from directory structure (e.g., app/api/users -> 'users' tag)
Path parameters are automatically detected from _param directories
Reference docs/api/openapi.mdx for OpenAPI configuration and best practices
Use c.SSE() to create Server-Sent Events streams for real-time updates
SSEWriter methods: Send(), SendData(), SendJSON(), SendComment(), SendRetry(), SendID(), IsClosed(), Close()
Always call defer sse.Close() and check sse.IsClosed() before sending in loops
Use c.Cookie(name) to read cookie values from requests
Use c.SetCookie(cookie) to set HTTP cookies on responses
Use c.GetBool(key) to retrieve boolean values from context storage
Deploy to Nexo Cloud with 'nexo login' then 'nexo deploy'
Nexo Cloud credentials are stored in ~/.nexo/credentials.json
Use 'nexo apps' to list, create, and delete cloud applications
Use 'nexo logs <app> -f' to stream logs in real-time
Use 'nexo status <app>' to view app status, deployments, and metrics
Use 'nexo env <app> set KEY=value' to configure environment variables
Use 'nexo domains <app> add <domain>' to add custom domains
Use 'nexo rollback <app>' to rollback to previous deployment
Configure cloud settings in nexo.yaml under the 'cloud' section (region, size, domains)
All cloud commands support --json flag for machine-readable output
